replies.msg:
Some of them do CARE, but 99% of them will not tell you unless you are their coworkers or you work for THEM !
They WILL show your more respect though if you can write, speak and communicate well... Grammar is only one part. Diction, sentence structure, style, etc..
However, it is important that you can help them understand what you are trying to say.

On the safe side, keep sentence short. If you are not confident, use less on complex sentence structure. Use direct tense.

In my opinion, keeping it straight forward and simple will be good start.

replies.msg:
listen to more English podcasts/watch western youtubers and perhaps get a hobby that requires you to be more proficient in English. It's honestly the amount of time that you immerse yourself in the language that matters. You'll pick up colloquialisms and other often used vocab if you make sure you're aware of them.

Honestly though getting an 8 in ielts doesn't depend that much on the spoken test. Make sure you can safely get 8.5 to 9 in the other parts and you're pretty much golden.

replies.msg: I can't offer much technical advice since I prefer learning the natural way personally, but it's a good idea to remind yourself of how native speakers talk while you type. For one, English sentences are very short in general and they often convey just one or two ideas. Pause and put a period/full stop before moving on to the next idea. Proofread every time you finish a paragraph. Make use of grammar checking tools too. They're not super effective but they can help you catch quite a few mistakes that you've overlooked. Look carefully at what mistakes you've made and be aware of the more frequent/serious ones. Jump through hoops one by one, and google whenever you're in doubt.

quote.msg: That’s fucking hilarious that the post creator judges English with DSE standard. The foreigners, especially the British and Americans, don’t really care any grammatical mistake. Don’t you experience many British judge people English? It is enough to convey your own messages and foreigners understand!

Some of them do CARE, but 99% of them will not tell you unless you are their coworkers or you work for THEM !
They WILL show your more respect though if you can write, speak and communicate well... Grammar is only one part. Diction, sentence structure, style, etc..
However, it is important that you can help them understand what you are trying to say.

On the safe side, keep sentence short. If you are not confident, use less on complex sentence structure. Use direct tense.

In my opinion, keeping it straight forward and simple will be good start.
